questions.title: Signal Amplitude Analysis with Noise
questions.question_text: When analyzing a noisy sinusoidal signal with amplitude $A = 3\,\text{V}$ using peak detection, how does the measured amplitude compare to the true value?
choices: Varies with each measurement due to random noise
Both B and C are correct
questions.correct_answer: Both B and C are correct
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Random noise causes measurement variability while keeping values relatively close to the true amplitude of $3\,\text{V}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Consider how random noise affects peak detection: it creates variability while keeping measurements near the true value.

questions.title: Phase Shift Effect on Amplitude
questions.question_text: For a sinusoid $A \cdot \sin(2\pi ft + \phi)$, what happens to the measured amplitude when phase $\phi$ changes from $\pi/4$ to $\pi/2$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Phase shift $\phi$ only affects timing, not the maximum amplitude $A$ of the sinusoid.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Phase $\phi$ shifts the signal in time but doesn't change the peak amplitude $A$.

questions.title: OOP Design Pattern Recognition
questions.question_text: Two classes - SignalGenerator and SignalAnalyzer - model real-world instruments with distinct responsibilities. This exemplifies which OOP principle?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Abstraction creates simplified models of complex real-world entities with clearly defined interfaces.
questions.feedback_incorrect: These classes model real instruments as abstract entities with specific responsibilities - this is abstraction.

questions.title: Aliasing in Video Sampling
questions.question_text: A fan rotating at $60\,\text{Hz}$ is recorded at $50$ frames/second. What aliasing effect occurs?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Undersampling at $f_s < 2f_0$ creates aliasing where $60\,\text{Hz}$ appears as $10\,\text{Hz}$ in reverse direction.
questions.feedback_incorrect: When sampling rate $f_s < 2f_0$, aliasing causes apparent reverse rotation at $|f_s - f_0|\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Stroboscopic Effect Definition
questions.question_text: In video systems, aliasing creates _______ effects where fast-moving objects appear to move erratically due to insufficient sampling.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Stroboscopic effects result from temporal aliasing in video sampling systems.
questions.feedback_incorrect: This visual phenomenon caused by undersampling is called the stroboscopic effect.

questions.title: Nyquist Frequency Calculation
questions.question_text: For a sampling frequency $f_s = 10\,\text{kHz}$, calculate the maximum signal frequency that can be accurately represented using the Nyquist criterion $f_{max} = f_s/2$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f_{max} = f_s/2 = 10\,\text{kHz}/2 = 5\,\text{kHz} = 5000\,\text{Hz}$ per Nyquist-Shannon theorem.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Apply Nyquist criterion: maximum frequency $= f_s/2 = 10\,\text{kHz}/2 = 5\,\text{kHz}$.

questions.title: Information Loss in Undersampling
questions.question_text: What occurs when a signal is sampled below the Nyquist rate $f_s < 2f_{max}$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Sampling below Nyquist rate causes irreversible information loss through frequency aliasing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Undersampling causes aliasing, making perfect signal reconstruction impossible.

questions.title: Digital Audio Sampling Requirements
questions.question_text: For CD-quality audio covering $20\,\text{Hz}$-$20\,\text{kHz}$, why is $44.1\,\text{kHz}$ sampling used?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f_s = 44.1\,\text{kHz} > 2 \times 20\,\text{kHz}$ satisfies Nyquist criterion for full audio spectrum capture.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Sampling at $44.1\,\text{kHz}$ ensures $f_s > 2f_{max} = 40\,\text{kHz}$ to prevent aliasing per Nyquist theorem.

questions.title: Aliasing Condition
questions.question_text: Aliasing occurs when the sampling frequency $f_s$ is less than twice the highest signal frequency: $f_s < 2f_{max}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! This violates the Nyquist-Shannon sampling theorem, causing aliasing distortion.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The Nyquist criterion requires $f_s \geq 2f_{max}$ to prevent aliasing.

questions.title: Signal Reconstruction Process
questions.question_text: In digital signal processing, 'reconstruction' refers to:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Reconstruction uses interpolation to rebuild continuous signals from discrete sample points.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Reconstruction is the process of converting discrete samples back to continuous-time signals.

questions.title: Aliasing Signal Distortion
questions.question_text: When aliasing occurs, the original signal becomes _______ and perfect reconstruction becomes impossible.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Aliasing introduces irreversible frequency distortion to the sampled signal.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Aliasing causes signal distortion that cannot be corrected post-sampling.

questions.title: Class Inheritance Implementation
questions.question_text: Which MATLAB syntax correctly implements class Vehicle inheriting from a superclass Transportation?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! MATLAB uses the < operator to specify inheritance: classdef ChildClass < ParentClass
questions.feedback_incorrect: MATLAB inheritance syntax uses < operator: classdef Vehicle < Transportation

questions.title: Phase Relationship Analysis
questions.question_text: Given two sinusoids with $90^\circ$ phase difference, which statement is correct?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Phase difference of $90^\circ = \pi/2\,\text{rad}$ can represent either $+90^\circ$ lead or $-90^\circ$ lag depending on reference.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Phase relationships are relative - the same $90^\circ$ difference can be interpreted as leading or lagging.

questions.title: Audio Aliasing Artifacts
questions.question_text: In digital audio, aliasing introduces unwanted _______ components not present in the original signal.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Aliasing creates phantom frequency components through spectral folding effects.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Aliasing generates spurious frequency components due to undersampling.

questions.title: Fourier Transform Frequency Resolution
questions.question_text: For an $N = 1024$-point FFT with sampling frequency $f_s = 8192\,\text{Hz}$, calculate the frequency resolution $\Delta f = f_s/N$ in Hz.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\Delta f = f_s/N = 8192\,\text{Hz}/1024 = 8\,\text{Hz}$ frequency bin spacing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency resolution: $\Delta f = f_s/N = 8192/1024 = 8\,\text{Hz}$ per bin.

questions.title: Phase Leading Definition
questions.question_text: For sinusoids $y_1(t) = A_1\sin(\omega t + \phi_1)$ and $y_2(t) = A_2\sin(\omega t + \phi_2)$, if $\phi_1 > \phi_2$, which statement is correct?
choices: $y_1$ reaches its peak value earlier in time
$y_1$ is shifted left on the graph
questions.correct_answer: $y_1$ reaches its peak value earlier in time
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Leading phase $\phi_1 > \phi_2$ means earlier peak occurrence in the time domain.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Phase shift $\phi$ only affects timing, not frequency $\omega$ or amplitude $A$.

questions.title: Nyquist Rate for 1 kHz Signal
questions.question_text: A signal contains frequencies up to $f_{max} = 1\,\text{kHz}$. What is the minimum Nyquist sampling rate $f_s$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Nyquist criterion requires $f_s > 2f_{max} = 2 \times 1\,\text{kHz} = 2\,\text{kHz}$ to prevent aliasing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Nyquist-Shannon theorem: sampling frequency must exceed twice the maximum signal frequency.

questions.title: Aliasing Prevention Scenarios
questions.question_text: Which sampling scenario guarantees NO aliasing for a signal with bandwidth $B = 8\,\text{kHz}$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Only oversampling with $f_s > 2B = 16\,\text{kHz}$ prevents aliasing per Nyquist criterion.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Undersampling ($f_s < 2B$) and critical sampling ($f_s = 2B$) both risk aliasing.

questions.title: Signal Reconstruction Importance
questions.question_text: Why is sampling above the Nyquist rate $f_s > 2f_{max}$ crucial for digital signal processing?
choices: Ensures perfect signal reconstruction without aliasing
questions.correct_answer: Ensures perfect signal reconstruction without aliasing
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Nyquist criterion guarantees sufficient information capture for accurate reconstruction.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The primary purpose is preventing aliasing distortion, enabling faithful signal reconstruction.

questions.title: Minimum Sampling Rate Calculation
questions.question_text: A signal has maximum frequency component $f_{max} = 5\,\text{kHz}$. Calculate the minimum practical sampling rate in kHz to avoid aliasing.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f_s > 2f_{max} = 2 \times 5\,\text{kHz} = 10\,\text{kHz}$, so $f_s \geq 10.1\,\text{kHz}$ satisfies Nyquist criterion.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Apply Nyquist theorem: $f_s$ must be greater than $2 \times 5\,\text{kHz} = 10\,\text{kHz}$.

questions.title: Perfect Reconstruction Limitations
questions.question_text: Sampling slightly above the Nyquist rate ($f_s \approx 2.01f_{max}$) guarantees perfect signal reconstruction in all practical systems.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Real systems have noise, non-ideal filters, and quantization effects that limit perfect reconstruction.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Practical limitations like thermal noise, filter roll-off, and finite precision prevent perfection.

questions.title: Anti-Aliasing Filter Design
questions.question_text: For a signal sampled at $f_s = 16\,\text{kHz}$, calculate the maximum anti-aliasing filter cutoff frequency $f_c$ in kHz.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f_c$ should be slightly below $f_s/2 = 16\,\text{kHz}/2 = 8\,\text{kHz}$ to prevent aliasing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Anti-aliasing filter cutoff: $f_c \leq f_s/2 = 16\,\text{kHz}/2 = 8\,\text{kHz}$

questions.title: Nyquist Rate Condition
questions.question_text: To avoid aliasing, the sampling frequency $f_s$ must be _______ twice the highest signal frequency: $f_s$ _____ $2f_{max}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Nyquist-Shannon theorem requires $f_s > 2f_{max}$ for alias-free sampling.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The strict inequality $f_s > 2f_{max}$ is essential to prevent frequency folding.

questions.title: Oversampling Benefits
questions.question_text: What is the primary advantage of sampling at $f_s \gg 2f_{max}$ (significant oversampling)?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Oversampling allows simpler, less steep anti-aliasing filters with wider transition bands.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Higher $f_s$ creates guard bands, making filter design less critical for aliasing prevention.

questions.title: Anti-Aliasing Filter Placement
questions.question_text: Where should an anti-aliasing filter with cutoff $f_c = f_s/2$ be positioned in a sampling system?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Anti-aliasing filters must be analog filters placed before sampling to remove high frequencies.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Aliasing prevention requires analog filtering before the sampling operation occurs.

questions.title: OOP Object Definition
questions.question_text: In object-oriented programming, an object represents:
choices: A blueprint for creating data structures
A function that operates on global variables
A real-world entity with properties and methods
A named variable storing primitive data
questions.correct_answer: A real-world entity with properties and methods
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Objects model real-world entities by encapsulating both data (properties) and behavior (methods).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Objects are instances that represent tangible or conceptual entities from the problem domain.

questions.title: Object Encapsulation
questions.question_text: What two fundamental elements does an object combine in OOP design?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Objects encapsulate data (properties/attributes) and operations (methods/functions) together.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Encapsulation binds data and the operations that manipulate that data into a single unit.

questions.title: Class vs Object Relationship
questions.question_text: What is the relationship between a class and an object in OOP?
choices: Class is a blueprint for creating objects
questions.correct_answer: Class is a blueprint for creating objects
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A class serves as a template/blueprint that defines the structure and behavior for object instances.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Classes define the template; objects are specific instances created from that template.

questions.title: Class Definition Scope
questions.question_text: A class definition specifies:
choices: Both structure and behavior of objects
questions.correct_answer: Both structure and behavior of objects
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Classes define both the data structure (attributes) and behaviors (methods) that objects will have.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Class definitions encompass both what objects contain (data) and what they can do (operations).

questions.title: Property Definition in OOP
questions.question_text: In OOP, a property (attribute) is:
choices: A named data field associated with objects
questions.correct_answer: A named data field associated with objects
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Properties are named data fields that store the state/characteristics of an object.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Properties hold the data that describes an object's current state and characteristics.

questions.title: Object Property Identification
questions.question_text: In a Car class definition, which element represents a property (attribute) rather than a method?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! 'color' is a data property that describes a characteristic of the car object.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Properties store data about objects. Methods like start() and stop() are actions, not characteristics.

questions.title: Method Definition in OOP
questions.question_text: In object-oriented programming, methods are:
choices: Functions that operate on object properties
questions.correct_answer: Functions that operate on object properties
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Methods are functions that define behaviors and operations for objects.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Methods are behavioral functions, not data storage or structural elements.

questions.title: Primary Method Function
questions.question_text: What is the primary purpose of methods in OOP design?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Methods encapsulate behaviors that manipulate and interact with object data.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Methods define actions and behaviors, not data storage or structural definitions.

questions.title: Object Instantiation Process
questions.question_text: In OOP, instantiation refers to:
choices: Creating object instances from class templates
questions.correct_answer: Creating object instances from class templates
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Instantiation is the process of creating specific object instances from class definitions.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Instantiation specifically refers to object creation, not modification or destruction.

questions.title: Class-Object Relationship Analogy
questions.question_text: Which analogy best describes the relationship between classes and object instantiation?
choices: Class is the cookie cutter, instantiation creates cookies
questions.correct_answer: Class is the cookie cutter, instantiation creates cookies
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Classes serve as templates (cookie cutter) that create multiple object instances (cookies).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Classes are templates that produce objects, like cookie cutters creating individual cookies.

questions.title: Encapsulation Principle
questions.question_text: What does encapsulation achieve in object-oriented design?
choices: Bundles data and methods while restricting external access
Enables global access to all object data
questions.correct_answer: Bundles data and methods while restricting external access
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Encapsulation creates data hiding and controlled access through defined interfaces.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Encapsulation is about data protection and controlled access, not performance or global visibility.

questions.title: Encapsulation Benefits
questions.question_text: What is the primary benefit of implementing encapsulation in software design?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Encapsulation improves code quality through data protection and interface clarity.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Encapsulation promotes better software engineering practices, not complexity or security reduction.

questions.title: Constructor Function Role
questions.question_text: What is the primary role of a constructor in OOP?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Constructors set initial values for object properties when instances are created.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Constructors specifically handle object initialization, not definition, display, or destruction.

questions.title: Constructor Invocation Timing
questions.question_text: When is a constructor automatically invoked in the object lifecycle?
choices: When new object instances are created
questions.correct_answer: When new object instances are created
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Constructors execute automatically during object instantiation to set initial state.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Constructor execution is tied specifically to object creation, not other lifecycle events.

questions.title: Signal Sampling Definition
questions.question_text: In digital signal processing, sampling a continuous signal means:
choices: Taking discrete measurements at regular time intervals $\Delta t$
questions.correct_answer: Taking discrete measurements at regular time intervals $\Delta t$
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Sampling captures signal values at discrete time points: $x[n] = x(n\Delta t)$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Sampling is the temporal discretization process, not format conversion or frequency analysis.

questions.title: Sampling Rate Definition
questions.question_text: The sampling rate $f_s$ (or sampling frequency) refers to:
choices: Frequency of discrete measurements per second
questions.correct_answer: Frequency of discrete measurements per second
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Sampling rate $f_s = 1/\Delta t$ determines how frequently signal measurements are taken.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Sampling rate specifically measures temporal frequency of data acquisition, not signal characteristics.

questions.title: Undersampling Consequences
questions.question_text: When the sampling rate $f_s$ is too low relative to signal frequency, what occurs?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Undersampling ($f_s < 2f_{max}$) causes aliasing, violating the Nyquist criterion.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Low sampling rates create aliasing artifacts, not amplification or frequency enhancement.

questions.title: Sampling Process Analogy
questions.question_text: Which analogy best represents the temporal sampling process?
choices: Taking photographs of moving objects at intervals
questions.correct_answer: Taking photographs of moving objects at intervals
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Photography captures discrete 'snapshots' at time intervals, like signal sampling.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Sampling involves discrete temporal capture, similar to photography, not continuous processes.

questions.title: Analog-to-Digital Conversion
questions.question_text: The process of converting continuous analog signals into discrete digital representations is called:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Sampling discretizes continuous signals in time, creating digital signal sequences.
questions.feedback_incorrect: While quantization and encoding are related, sampling specifically handles temporal discretization.

questions.title: Sampling Rate and Quality Relationship
questions.question_text: Higher sampling rates $f_s$ always improve digital signal representation quality and reduce aliasing effects.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Higher $f_s$ provides better temporal resolution and reduces aliasing, improving signal fidelity.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Increased sampling rates capture more signal information, reducing aliasing and improving quality.

questions.title: Cosine Function Analysis
questions.question_text: For the function $i(t) = 10\cos(4\pi t)$, calculate the frequency $f$ in Hz using $f = \omega/(2\pi)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\omega = 4\pi\,\text{rad/s}$, so $f = 4\pi/(2\pi) = 2\,\text{Hz}$. Amplitude $A = 10$, phase $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Extract $\omega$ from the argument: $4\pi t$ means $\omega = 4\pi$, then $f = \omega/(2\pi) = 2\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Cosine Wave Parameters
questions.question_text: For $i(t) = 10\cos(4\pi t)$, identify the amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $A = 10$, $\omega = 4\pi$ gives $f = 2\,\text{Hz}$, and no phase term means $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Standard form: $A\cos(\omega t + \phi)$. Here $A = 10$, $\omega = 4\pi \rightarrow f = 2\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = 0$.

questions.title: Phase-Shifted Sine Analysis
questions.question_text: For $v(t) = 2\sin(2\pi t + \pi/2)$, calculate the frequency $f$ in Hz.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\omega = 2\pi\,\text{rad/s}$, so $f = 2\pi/(2\pi) = 1\,\text{Hz}$. $A = 2$, $\phi = \pi/2$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: From $2\pi t$ coefficient: $\omega = 2\pi$, therefore $f = \omega/(2\pi) = 1\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Sine Wave with Phase Shift
questions.question_text: For $v(t) = 2\sin(2\pi t + \pi/2)$, determine amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $A = 2$, $\omega = 2\pi$ gives $f = 1\,\text{Hz}$, phase shift $\phi = \pi/2$ radians.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Standard form: $A \sin(\omega t + \phi)$. Extract $A = 2$, $\omega = 2\pi \to f = 1\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = \pi/2$.

questions.title: Negative Amplitude Cosine
questions.question_text: For $i(t) = -3\cos(6\pi t)$, what are the correct amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Amplitude $A$ is always positive: $A = 3$. $\omega = 6\pi$ gives $f = 3\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Amplitude $A = |\text{coefficient}| = 3$ (always positive). $\omega = 6\pi \to f = 6\pi/(2\pi) = 3\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Sine Wave Parameter Analysis
questions.question_text: For the sinusoidal function $v(t) = 0.5\sin(8\pi t)$, calculate the frequency $f$ in $\text{Hz}$ using $f = \omega/(2\pi)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\omega = 8\pi\,\text{rad/s}$, so $f = 8\pi/(2\pi) = 4\,\text{Hz}$. Amplitude $A = 0.5$, phase $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Extract angular frequency: $\omega = 8\pi$ from $8\pi t$, then apply $f = \omega/(2\pi) = 8\pi/(2\pi) = 4\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Complete Sine Wave Analysis
questions.question_text: For $v(t) = 0.5\sin(8\pi t)$, determine amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $A = 0.5$, $\omega = 8\pi$ gives $f = 4\,\text{Hz}$, no phase term means $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Standard form: $A \sin(\omega t + \phi)$. Here $A = 0.5$, $\omega = 8\pi \to f = 4\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = 0$.

questions.title: Frequency from Period Analysis
questions.question_text: A sine wave completes one full cycle in $T = 1.0\,\text{s}$. Calculate its frequency $f$ using $f = 1/T$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f = 1/T = 1/1.0\,\text{s} = 1.0\,\text{Hz}$. Frequency is the reciprocal of period.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use the relationship $f = 1/T$ where $T$ is the period. $f = 1/1.0\,\text{s} = 1.0\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Phase Shift Identification
questions.question_text: For a standard sine wave $y(t) = \sin(\omega t)$ with no horizontal displacement, the phase shift $\phi = \_\_\_\_\_$ radians.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Standard sine function $\sin(\omega t)$ has $\phi = 0$ (no phase shift).
questions.feedback_incorrect: A standard sine wave with no horizontal shift has phase $\phi = 0$ radians.

questions.title: Cosine Amplitude Measurement
questions.question_text: A cosine wave oscillates between $+2\,\text{V}$ and $-2\,\text{V}$. Calculate its amplitude $A$ in volts.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Amplitude $A = (\text{max} - \text{min})/2 = (2\,\text{V} - (-2\,\text{V}))/2 = 2\,\text{V}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Amplitude is half the peak-to-peak value: $A = (V_{max} - V_{min})/2 = 4\,\text{V}/2 = 2\,\text{V}$.

questions.title: Phase-Shifted Cosine Analysis
questions.question_text: A cosine wave shows a phase shift of $\phi = \pi/4$ radians. This represents:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\phi = \pi/4\,\text{rad} = 45\text{\degree}$ phase shift in degrees.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Convert radians to degrees: $\phi = \pi/4 \times (180\text{\degree}/\pi) = 45\text{\degree}$.

questions.title: Complex Sinusoidal Function
questions.question_text: For a sinusoidal function with $A = 2, f = 1\,\text{Hz}, \phi = \pi/2$, determine the complete parameters:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The parameters match: amplitude $A = 2$, frequency $f = 1\,\text{Hz}$, phase $\phi = \pi/2$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Check each parameter: $A = 2$ (amplitude), $f = 1\,\text{Hz}$ (frequency), $\phi = \pi/2$ (phase).

questions.title: Trigonometric Identity Application
questions.question_text: The function $y = 2\sin^2(x)$ can be rewritten using the identity $\sin^2(x) = (1 - \cos(2x))/2$ as:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $y = 2\sin^2(x) = 2 \times (1 - \cos(2x))/2 = 1 - \cos(2x)$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Apply identity: $y = 2\sin^2(x) = 2 \times (1 - \cos(2x))/2 = 1 - \cos(2x)$.

questions.title: Sound Wave Frequency Analysis
questions.question_text: A sound wave representing musical note $A_4$ has frequency $f = 440\,\text{Hz}$. Calculate its period $T$ in milliseconds using $T = 1/f$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $T = 1/f = 1/440\,\text{Hz} = 0.00227\,\text{s} = 2.27\,\text{ms}$ for $A_4$ pitch.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Period $T = 1/f = 1/440\,\text{Hz} = 0.00227\,\text{s} = 2.27\,\text{ms}$. Convert seconds to milliseconds.

questions.title: Frequency Domain Audio Processing
questions.question_text: Which application primarily utilizes frequency domain analysis for signal enhancement?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Audio filtering targets specific frequency bands to remove noise while preserving desired signals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency domain analysis is essential for filtering applications that manipulate specific frequency components.

questions.title: FM Radio Frequency Identification
questions.question_text: Why are FM radio stations identified by frequency (e.g., "$95.5\,\text{FM}$")?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! FM stations use frequency modulation at specific carrier frequencies: $95.5\,\text{MHz}$ in this example.
questions.feedback_incorrect: FM radio stations are identified by their carrier frequency in the VHF band ($88-108\,\text{MHz}$).

questions.title: Audio Equalizer Frequency Manipulation
questions.question_text: Audio equalizers adjust amplitude gains for different frequency bands, demonstrating practical frequency domain signal processing.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Equalizers implement frequency-selective gain control using band-pass filters and frequency domain principles.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Equalizers are classic examples of frequency domain applications, adjusting specific frequency ranges independently.

questions.title: Low-Pass Filter Frequency Response
questions.question_text: How does a low-pass filter operate in the frequency domain?
choices: Passes low frequencies, attenuates high frequencies
questions.correct_answer: Passes low frequencies, attenuates high frequencies
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Low-pass filters: $H(\omega) \approx 1$ for $\omega < \omega_c$ and $H(\omega) \approx 0$ for $\omega > \omega_c$ (cutoff frequency).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Low-pass filters selectively pass frequencies below the cutoff frequency $\omega_c$ while attenuating higher frequencies.

questions.title: Cellular Communication Frequency Bands
questions.question_text: Cell phones utilize multiple frequency bands (e.g., $850\,\text{MHz}$, $1900\,\text{MHz}$, $2.4\,\text{GHz}$) for communication with base stations.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Cellular systems use frequency division multiple access (FDMA) across various bands for different services.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Modern cell phones operate across multiple frequency bands to support different protocols and coverage areas.

questions.title: Band-Pass Filter Audio Application
questions.question_text: In audio processing, what function does a band-pass filter serve?
choices: Passes only frequencies within range $[f_1, f_2]$
questions.correct_answer: Passes only frequencies within range $[f_1, f_2]$
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Band-pass filters: $H(\omega) \neq 0$ for $\omega_1 \le \omega \le \omega_2$, $H(\omega) \approx 0$ elsewhere.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Band-pass filters selectively pass frequencies within a defined bandwidth while rejecting frequencies outside this range.

questions.title: WiFi Channel Frequency Calculation
questions.question_text: WiFi operates in $2.4\,\text{GHz}$ ISM band. If Channel 1 uses $2.412\,\text{GHz}$ and channels are spaced $5\,\text{MHz}$ apart, calculate Channel 6 frequency in $\text{GHz}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Channel 6 = $2.412\,\text{GHz} + (6-1) \times 0.005\,\text{GHz} = 2.412 + 0.025 = 2.437\,\text{GHz}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use frequency formula: $f_6 = f_1 + (\text{channel_offset}) \times \text{spacing} = 2.412 + 5 \times 0.005 = 2.437\,\text{GHz}$.

questions.title: Circuit Oscillation Analysis
questions.question_text: How would an engineer diagnose unwanted oscillations in an electronic circuit?
choices: Frequency spectrum analysis to identify problematic frequencies
questions.correct_answer: Frequency spectrum analysis to identify problematic frequencies
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Spectrum analysis reveals oscillation frequencies, enabling targeted troubleshooting and filter design.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency domain analysis using spectrum analyzers identifies oscillation frequencies for effective circuit debugging.

questions.title: Pure Sine Wave Spectrum
questions.question_text: A pure sinusoid $x(t) = A \sin(2\pi f_0 t)$ at $f_0 = 100\,\text{Hz}$ produces what frequency spectrum?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Pure sinusoids have discrete spectra: $X(f) = (A/2j)[\delta(f-f_0) - \delta(f+f_0)]$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A pure sine wave contains only one frequency component, appearing as a single spike in the frequency domain.

questions.title: Primary Fourier Transform Purpose
questions.question_text: The fundamental purpose of Fourier Transform in signal analysis is:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier Transform reveals frequency composition through domain transformation: $x(t) \to X(\omega)$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The primary function is mathematical transformation from temporal to spectral representation.

questions.title: Non-Typical Fourier Applications
questions.question_text: Which application does NOT typically require Fourier Transform analysis?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Instantaneous measurements are time-domain operations; Fourier analysis reveals frequency content over intervals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier Transform analyzes frequency content, not instantaneous time-domain measurements.

questions.title: Information Limitations in Fourier Analysis
questions.question_text: Standard Fourier Transform $X(\omega)$ does NOT directly provide:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier Transform provides global frequency information but sacrifices temporal localization (uncertainty principle).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Standard Fourier analysis loses time information; Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) provides time-frequency analysis.

questions.title: Signal Processing Contributions
questions.question_text: Fourier analysis enables signal processing through:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier analysis underlies spectral analysis, filtering, convolution, modulation, and frequency domain processing.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier Transform is foundational for virtually all frequency-based signal processing operations.

questions.title: Domain Conversion Definition
questions.question_text: The Fourier Transform converts signals from time domain $x(t)$ to \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ domain $X(\omega)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier Transform performs time-to-frequency domain conversion: $x(t) \leftrightarrow X(\omega)$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The fundamental operation transforms temporal signals into their frequency domain representations.

questions.title: Frequency Spectrum Representation
questions.question_text: The frequency spectrum displays the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ $|X(\omega)|$ of different frequency components in signal $x(t)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Frequency spectrum plots magnitude $|X(\omega)|$ showing amplitude distribution across frequencies $\omega$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The spectrum visualizes how signal amplitudes vary across different frequency components.

questions.title: Complex Signal Decomposition
questions.question_text: Complex signals like music decompose into constituent frequency \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ through Fourier Transform analysis.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Fourier analysis separates complex waveforms into individual frequency components or harmonics.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Complex signals contain multiple frequency components that can be identified using Fourier analysis.

questions.title: Time Domain Reconstruction
questions.question_text: To convert frequency domain $X(\omega)$ back to time domain $x(t)$, apply the \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ Fourier Transform.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Inverse Fourier Transform: $x(t) = F^{-1}\{X(\omega)\}$ reverses the frequency-to-time conversion.
questions.feedback_incorrect: The Inverse Fourier Transform reconstructs time-domain signals from frequency domain data.

questions.title: Periodic Signal Analysis Effectiveness
questions.question_text: Fourier Transform is particularly effective for periodic signals due to their discrete \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ content.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Periodic signals have well-defined frequency spectra with discrete components at harmonics.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Periodic signals with fundamental frequency $f_0$ and harmonics create clear spectral lines.

questions.title: Dominant Frequency Identification
questions.question_text: In frequency spectrum analysis, dominant frequencies appear as peaks with maximum \_\_\_\_\_\_\_ $|X(\omega)|$ values.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Spectral peaks with highest $|X(\omega)|$ indicate the strongest frequency components.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Large amplitude values in the spectrum correspond to dominant frequency components.

questions.title: Comprehensive Fourier Transform Application

questions.feedback_incorrect: Audio equalization demonstrates practical Fourier analysis: spectral identification for frequency-specific processing.

questions.title: Dominant Frequency Peak Identification
questions.question_text: In a frequency spectrum with a clear peak at $f = 1\,\text{kHz}$, the dominant frequency component is:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The dominant frequency corresponds to the highest amplitude peak in the spectrum.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Dominant frequencies are identified by locating the maximum amplitude peaks in the spectrum.

questions.title: Multi-Component Spectrum Analysis
questions.question_text: A frequency spectrum displaying multiple distinct peaks indicates:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Multiple peaks indicate superposition of different frequency components in the original signal.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Each spectral peak represents a distinct frequency component in the complex signal.

questions.title: Single Peak Spectrum Interpretation
questions.question_text: A frequency spectrum with one sharp peak most likely represents:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Single spectral peak indicates a pure sinusoidal tone at that frequency.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Pure sine waves produce single-frequency spectra with one dominant peak.

questions.title: Harmonic Pattern Recognition
questions.question_text: Evenly spaced spectral peaks at frequencies $f_0, 2f_0, 3f_0, 4f_0...$ indicate:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Harmonic series appears as evenly spaced peaks at integer multiples of fundamental frequency $f_0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Periodic signals generate harmonic spectra with peaks at $nf_0$ where $n = 1, 2, 3, ...$

questions.title: Noise Spectrum Characteristics
questions.question_text: A broad, flat spectral region across frequencies typically indicates:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Broadband noise exhibits flat spectral density across wide frequency ranges.
questions.feedback_incorrect: White noise and random signals appear as relatively flat, broad spectral distributions.

questions.title: Spectral Peak Height Interpretation
questions.question_text: Varying peak heights in frequency spectrum $|X(\omega)|$ represent:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Peak height directly corresponds to $|X(\omega)|$, the amplitude of each frequency component.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Spectral magnitude $|X(\omega)|$ shows the relative amplitudes of different frequency components.

questions.title: SI Unit for Electric Charge
questions.question_text: What is the standard SI unit used to measure electric charge?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The Coulomb (C) is the SI base unit for electric charge, defined as the charge transported by 1A of current in 1s.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Remember: V measures voltage, A measures current, $\Omega$ measures resistance. The Coulomb (C) measures charge.

questions.title: Elementary Charge Magnitude
questions.question_text: The elementary charge $e$ represents the fundamental unit of electric charge. What is its approximate magnitude?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $e = 1.602 \times 10^{-19}\ \text{C}$ is the magnitude of charge on a proton ($+e$) or electron ($-e$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: The elementary charge $e = 1.602 \times 10^{-19}\ \text{C}$. Note: $6.02 \times 10^{23}$ is Avogadro's number, $9.11 \times 10^{-31}$ is electron mass.

questions.title: Current Definition
questions.question_text: Electric current $I$ is fundamentally defined as the rate of flow of electric charge. What creates current in a conductor?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Current $I = dQ/dt$ represents moving charges (electrons in metals, ions in electrolytes).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Current requires charge motion. Static fields don't create current; magnetic fields alone don't move charges.

questions.title: Coulomb's Law Force Characteristics
questions.question_text: Coulomb's Law $F = k_0q_1q_2/r^2$ describes electrostatic force. Unlike gravitational force, electric force can:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Electric force is attractive for opposite charges ($\pm$) and repulsive for like charges ($++,--$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Electric forces depend on charge signs: opposite charges attract, like charges repel. Gravity only attracts.

questions.title: Electrostatics Field Sources
questions.question_text: Electrostatics analyzes electric fields $\vec{E}$ created by which type of charge distributions?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Electrostatics deals with stationary charges ($\partial\rho/\partial t = 0$), where $\rho$ is charge density.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Electrostatics assumes static charges. Time-varying currents and accelerating charges belong to electrodynamics.

questions.title: Sine Wave with Phase Shift
questions.question_text: For $v(t) = 2\sin(2\pi t + \pi/2)$, determine amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $A = 2$, $\omega = 2\pi$ gives $f = 1\,\text{Hz}$, phase shift $\phi = \pi/2$ radians.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Standard form: $A \sin(\omega t + \phi)$. Extract $A = 2$, $\omega = 2\pi \to f = 1\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = \pi/2$.

questions.title: Negative Amplitude Cosine
questions.question_text: For $i(t) = -3\cos(6\pi t)$, what are the correct amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Amplitude $A$ is always positive: $A = 3$. $\omega = 6\pi$ gives $f = 3\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Amplitude $A = |\text{coefficient}| = 3$ (always positive). $\omega = 6\pi \to f = 6\pi/(2\pi) = 3\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Sine Wave Parameter Analysis
questions.question_text: For the sinusoidal function $v(t) = 0.5\sin(8\pi t)$, calculate the frequency $f$ in $\text{Hz}$ using $f = \omega/(2\pi)$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\omega = 8\pi\,\text{rad/s}$, so $f = 8\pi/(2\pi) = 4\,\text{Hz}$. Amplitude $A = 0.5$, phase $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Extract angular frequency: $\omega = 8\pi$ from $8\pi t$, then apply $f = \omega/(2\pi) = 8\pi/(2\pi) = 4\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Complete Sine Wave Analysis
questions.question_text: For $v(t) = 0.5\sin(8\pi t)$, determine amplitude $A$, frequency $f$, and phase $\phi$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $A = 0.5$, $\omega = 8\pi$ gives $f = 4\,\text{Hz}$, no phase term means $\phi = 0$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Standard form: $A \sin(\omega t + \phi)$. Here $A = 0.5$, $\omega = 8\pi \to f = 4\,\text{Hz}$, $\phi = 0$.

questions.title: Frequency from Period Analysis
questions.question_text: A sine wave completes one full cycle in $T = 1.0\,\text{s}$. Calculate its frequency $f$ using $f = 1/T$:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $f = 1/T = 1/1.0\,\text{s} = 1.0\,\text{Hz}$. Frequency is the reciprocal of period.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use the relationship $f = 1/T$ where $T$ is the period. $f = 1/1.0\,\text{s} = 1.0\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.title: Phase Shift Identification
questions.question_text: For a standard sine wave $y(t) = \sin(\omega t)$ with no horizontal displacement, the phase shift $\phi = \_\_\_\_\_$ radians.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Standard sine function $\sin(\omega t)$ has $\phi = 0$ (no phase shift).
questions.feedback_incorrect: A standard sine wave with no horizontal shift has phase $\phi = 0$ radians.

questions.title: Cosine Amplitude Measurement
questions.question_text: A cosine wave oscillates between $+2\,\text{V}$ and $-2\,\text{V}$. Calculate its amplitude $A$ in volts.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Amplitude $A = (\text{max} - \text{min})/2 = (2\,\text{V} - (-2\,\text{V}))/2 = 2\,\text{V}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Amplitude is half the peak-to-peak value: $A = (V_{max} - V_{min})/2 = 4\,\text{V}/2 = 2\,\text{V}$.

questions.title: Phase-Shifted Cosine Analysis
questions.question_text: A cosine wave shows a phase shift of $\phi = \pi/4$ radians. This represents:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $\phi = \pi/4\,\text{rad} = 45\text{\degree}$ phase shift in degrees.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Convert radians to degrees: $\phi = \pi/4 \times (180\text{\degree}/\pi) = 45\text{\degree}$.

questions.title: Complex Sinusoidal Function
questions.question_text: For a sinusoidal function with $A = 2, f = 1\,\text{Hz}, \phi = \pi/2$, determine the complete parameters:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! The parameters match: amplitude $A = 2$, frequency $f = 1\,\text{Hz}$, phase $\phi = \pi/2$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Check each parameter: $A = 2$ (amplitude), $f = 1\,\text{Hz}$ (frequency), $\phi = \pi/2$ (phase).

questions.title: Trigonometric Identity Application
questions.question_text: The function $y = 2\sin^2(x)$ can be rewritten using the identity $\sin^2(x) = (1 - \cos(2x))/2$ as:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $y = 2\sin^2(x) = 2 \times (1 - \cos(2x))/2 = 1 - \cos(2x)$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Apply identity: $y = 2\sin^2(x) = 2 \times (1 - \cos(2x))/2 = 1 - \cos(2x)$.

questions.title: Sound Wave Frequency Analysis
questions.question_text: A sound wave representing musical note $A_4$ has frequency $f = 440\,\text{Hz}$. Calculate its period $T$ in milliseconds using $T = 1/f$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $T = 1/f = 1/440\,\text{Hz} = 0.00227\,\text{s} = 2.27\,\text{ms}$ for $A_4$ pitch.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Period $T = 1/f = 1/440\,\text{Hz} = 0.00227\,\text{s} = 2.27\,\text{ms}$. Convert seconds to milliseconds.

questions.title: Frequency Domain Audio Processing
questions.question_text: Which application primarily utilizes frequency domain analysis for signal enhancement?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Audio filtering targets specific frequency bands to remove noise while preserving desired signals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency domain analysis is essential for filtering applications that manipulate specific frequency components.

questions.title: FM Radio Frequency Identification
questions.question_text: Why are FM radio stations identified by frequency (e.g., "$95.5\,\text{FM}$")?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! FM stations use frequency modulation at specific carrier frequencies: $95.5\,\text{MHz}$ in this example.
questions.feedback_incorrect: FM radio stations are identified by their carrier frequency in the VHF band ($88-108\,\text{MHz}$).

questions.title: Audio Equalizer Frequency Manipulation
questions.question_text: Audio equalizers adjust amplitude gains for different frequency bands, demonstrating practical frequency domain signal processing.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Equalizers implement frequency-selective gain control using band-pass filters and frequency domain principles.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Equalizers are classic examples of frequency domain applications, adjusting specific frequency ranges independently.

questions.title: Low-Pass Filter Frequency Response
questions.question_text: How does a low-pass filter operate in the frequency domain?
choices: Passes low frequencies, attenuates high frequencies
questions.correct_answer: Passes low frequencies, attenuates high frequencies
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Low-pass filters: $H(\omega) \approx 1$ for $\omega < \omega_c$ and $H(\omega) \approx 0$ for $\omega > \omega_c$ (cutoff frequency).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Low-pass filters selectively pass frequencies below the cutoff frequency $\omega_c$ while attenuating higher frequencies.

questions.title: Cellular Communication Frequency Bands
questions.question_text: Cell phones utilize multiple frequency bands (e.g., $850\,\text{MHz}$, $1900\,\text{MHz}$, $2.4\,\text{GHz}$) for communication with base stations.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Cellular systems use frequency division multiple access (FDMA) across various bands for different services.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Modern cell phones operate across multiple frequency bands to support different protocols and coverage areas.

questions.title: Band-Pass Filter Audio Application
questions.question_text: In audio processing, what function does a band-pass filter serve?
choices: Passes only frequencies within range $[f_1, f_2]$
questions.correct_answer: Passes only frequencies within range $[f_1, f_2]$
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Band-pass filters: $H(\omega) \neq 0$ for $\omega_1 \le \omega \le \omega_2$, $H(\omega) \approx 0$ elsewhere.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Band-pass filters selectively pass frequencies within a defined bandwidth while rejecting frequencies outside this range.

questions.title: WiFi Channel Frequency Calculation
questions.question_text: WiFi operates in $2.4\,\text{GHz}$ ISM band. If Channel 1 uses $2.412\,\text{GHz}$ and channels are spaced $5\,\text{MHz}$ apart, calculate Channel 6 frequency in $\text{GHz}$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Channel 6 = $2.412\,\text{GHz} + (6-1) \times 0.005\,\text{GHz} = 2.412 + 0.025 = 2.437\,\text{GHz}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use frequency formula: $f_6 = f_1 + (\text{channel_offset}) \times \text{spacing} = 2.412 + 5 \times 0.005 = 2.437\,\text{GHz}$.

questions.title: Circuit Oscillation Analysis
questions.question_text: How would an engineer diagnose unwanted oscillations in an electronic circuit?
choices: Frequency spectrum analysis to identify problematic frequencies

questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency domain analysis using spectrum analyzers identifies oscillation frequencies for effective circuit debugging.

questions.title: Pure Sine Wave Spectrum
questions.question_text: A pure sinusoid $x(t) = A \sin(2\pi f_0 t)$ at $f_0 = 100\,\text{Hz}$ produces what frequency spectrum?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Pure sinusoids have discrete spectra: $X(f) = (A/2j)[\delta(f-f_0) - \delta(f+f_0)]$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A pure sine wave contains only one frequency component, appearing as a single spike in the frequency domain.

questions.title: Frequency Spectrum Amplitude Interpretation
questions.question_text: In a frequency spectrum plot, the height of each spectral line represents:
choices: Amplitude or energy of frequency component
questions.correct_answer: Amplitude or energy of frequency component
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Spectral magnitude $|X(f)|$ indicates the amplitude/energy content at each frequency.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Frequency spectrum height represents the magnitude or energy content of each frequency component in the signal.

questions.title: Dual-Tone Signal Spectrum
questions.question_text: The spectrum of $x(t) = A_1\sin(2\pi\cdot 100t) + A_2\sin(2\pi\cdot 200t)$ with $A_1 = A_2$ shows:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Linear superposition: each sinusoid contributes independently to the frequency spectrum.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Superposition principle: multiple sinusoids appear as separate spectral lines at their respective frequencies.

questions.title: Silent Signal Spectrum Interpretation
questions.question_text: A frequency spectrum with no visible spikes necessarily indicates a completely silent signal (zero amplitude).
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Low-amplitude signals or noise floors may not show visible spikes but still contain energy.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Signals may have low amplitude below display threshold or contain broadband noise not visible as discrete spikes.

questions.title: DC Component Spectrum Identification
questions.question_text: A large spectral component at $f = 0\,\text{Hz}$ indicates the signal contains:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $X(0)$ represents the DC component: $\int x(t)dt$, the signal's average value.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A spike at $0\,\text{Hz}$ (DC) indicates a constant offset or average value in the time-domain signal.

questions.title: Zero-Mean Sine Wave Spectrum
questions.question_text: For $x(t) = 5\sin(2\pi\cdot 10t)$ with zero DC offset, identify the number of spectral peaks in the magnitude spectrum.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Zero-mean sinusoid produces one peak at $f = 10\,\text{Hz}$ (ignoring negative frequencies in magnitude spectrum).
questions.feedback_incorrect: A pure sinusoid with no DC offset creates a single spectral line at its fundamental frequency.

questions.title: Signal Complexity Correlation
questions.question_text: Signals with many spectral components typically appear more complex in the time domain than signals with few frequency components.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! More frequency components create more complex time-domain waveforms through superposition.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Fourier theory: complex time signals result from superposition of multiple frequency components.

questions.title: Equal-Amplitude Multi-Tone Analysis
questions.question_text: A spectrum with equal-height spikes at $100\,\text{Hz}$, $200\,\text{Hz}$, $300\,\text{Hz}$, and $400\,\text{Hz}$ indicates:
choices: Equal energy at these four frequencies
questions.correct_answer: Equal energy at these four frequencies
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Equal spectral magnitudes indicate equal energy distribution across these frequency components.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Spectral line heights represent energy distribution; equal heights mean equal energy at those frequencies.

questions.title: Series Inductors Calculation
questions.question_text: Calculate the total inductance when two inductors $L_1 = 5\,\text{H}$ and $L_2 = 5\,\text{H}$ are connected in series. Express answer in henries (H).
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For series inductors: $L_{\text{total}} = L_1 + L_2 = 5\,\text{H} + 5\,\text{H} = 10\,\text{H}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use series formula: $L_{\text{total}} = L_1 + L_2$. Series inductors add directly like resistors.

questions.title: Parallel Inductors Calculation
questions.question_text: Calculate the total inductance when two inductors $L_1 = 6\,\text{H}$ and $L_2 = 6\,\text{H}$ are connected in parallel. Express answer in henries (H).
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For parallel inductors: $1/L_{\text{total}} = 1/L_1 + 1/L_2 = 1/6 + 1/6 = 1/3$, so $L_{\text{total}} = 3\,\text{H}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use parallel formula: $1/L_{\text{total}} = 1/L_1 + 1/L_2$. For equal inductors: $L_{\text{total}} = L/n$ where $n$ is the number of inductors.

questions.title: Right-Hand Rule for Magnetic Field
questions.question_text: Using the right-hand rule to determine magnetic field direction around a current-carrying wire:
questions.correct_answer: Thumb = current direction, fingers curl = $\vec{B}$ direction
choices: Thumb = current direction, fingers curl = $\vec{B}$ direction
Thumb = $\vec{B}$ direction, fingers curl = current direction
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Right-hand rule: thumb points in current direction, fingers curl in direction of magnetic field $\vec{B}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Right-hand rule: align thumb with current direction, curved fingers show magnetic field $\vec{B}$ direction.

questions.title: Factors NOT Affecting Inductance
questions.question_text: When calculating the inductance $L$ of a coil using $L = \mu_0\mu_r N^2 A/\ell$, which parameter does NOT affect the result?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Wire resistance R affects power loss but not inductance L. Inductance depends on geometry and permeability.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Inductance L depends on turns N, area A, length $\ell$, and permeability $\mu$. Wire resistance is separate from inductance.

questions.title: Core Permeability Effect on Inductance
questions.question_text: How does the relative permeability $\mu_r$ of the core material affect inductance in the formula $L = \mu_0\mu_r N^2 A/\ell$?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Higher $\mu_r$ increases magnetic flux density $\vec{B} = \mu\vec{H}$, enhancing magnetic coupling and inductance L.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Permeability $\mu_r$ affects how well the core material supports magnetic fields, directly influencing inductance.

questions.title: Parallel Inductors Formula
questions.question_text: For three inductors $L_1$, $L_2$, and $L_3$ connected in parallel, which formula correctly calculates total inductance?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Parallel inductors combine like parallel resistors: reciprocal of total equals sum of reciprocals.
questions.feedback_incorrect: Parallel inductors: $1/L_{\text{total}} = 1/L_1 + 1/L_2 + 1/L_3$. This is opposite to series combination.

questions.title: Inductor Energy Storage Mechanism
questions.question_text: An inductor stores energy in an electric field between its windings.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Inductors store energy in magnetic fields: $E = \frac{1}{2}LI^2$. Capacitors store energy in electric fields.
questions.feedback_incorrect: False. Inductors store energy in magnetic fields ($E = \frac{1}{2}LI^2$), while capacitors store energy in electric fields.

questions.title: Series Inductors Combination Rule
questions.question_text: The total inductance of inductors connected in series equals the sum of their individual inductances: $L_{\text{total}} = L_1 + L_2 + ... + L_n$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Series inductors add directly: $L_{\text{total}} = \sum L_i$, similar to series resistors.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. Series inductors combine by direct addition, just like series resistors.

questions.title: Turn Count Effect on Inductance
questions.question_text: The inductance of a coil decreases when the number of turns $N$ increases, keeping all other parameters constant.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Inductance $L \propto N^2$ increases quadratically with turn count due to increased magnetic flux linkage.
questions.feedback_incorrect: False. Inductance $L \propto N^2$ increases with the square of the number of turns.

questions.title: Parallel Inductors Total Value
questions.question_text: When inductors are connected in parallel, the total inductance $L_{\text{total}}$ is always smaller than the smallest individual inductor value.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Parallel combination: $1/L_{\text{total}} = \sum(1/L_i)$ always gives $L_{\text{total}} < L_{\text{min}}$, like parallel resistors.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. Parallel combination always reduces total inductance below the smallest individual value.

questions.title: Coil Diameter Effect on Inductance
questions.question_text: A coil with larger diameter (cross-sectional area $A$) has lower inductance than a smaller diameter coil, assuming all other factors remain constant.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! From $L = \mu_0\mu_r N^2 A/\ell$, inductance $L \propto A$ increases with cross-sectional area (diameter$^2$).
questions.feedback_incorrect: False. Larger diameter increases area A, which increases inductance $L \propto A$ in the inductance formula.

questions.title: Inductor Voltage-Current Rate Relationship
questions.question_text: The voltage across an inductor $V_L$ is directly proportional to the rate of change of current through it ($dI_L/dt$).
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Faraday's law gives $V_L = L(dI_L/dt)$, showing direct proportionality between voltage and current rate.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. The fundamental inductor equation $V_L = L(dI_L/dt)$ shows this direct proportionality.

questions.title: Constant Current Through Inductor
questions.question_text: When current through an inductor is constant ($dI_L/dt = 0$), the voltage across the inductor equals zero.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! $V_L = L(dI_L/dt) = L(0) = 0\,\text{V}$ when current is constant. Inductor acts like short circuit for DC steady state.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. From $V_L = L(dI_L/dt)$, constant current ($dI_L/dt = 0$) results in zero voltage across the inductor.

questions.title: Inductor Energy Storage Calculation
questions.question_text: Calculate the energy stored in a $2\,\text{H}$ inductor carrying a steady current of $3\,\text{A}$. Use $E = \frac{1}{2}LI^2$. Express answer in joules (J).
questions.feedback_incorrect: Use $E = \frac{1}{2}LI^2$. Substitute: $L = 2\,\text{H}$, $I = 3\,\text{A}$. Calculate: $\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 3^2 = 9\,\text{J}$.

questions.title: Coil Length Effect on Inductance
questions.question_text: For a given coil with fixed turns $N$, cross-sectional area $A$, and permeability $\mu$, a shorter coil length $\ell$ results in higher inductance $L$ according to $L = \mu N^2 A/\ell$.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! From $L = \mu N^2 A/\ell$, inductance is inversely proportional to coil length. Shorter $\ell$ increases magnetic flux density.
questions.feedback_incorrect: True. The inductance formula $L = \mu N^2 A/\ell$ shows inverse relationship with length $\ell$.

questions.title: Wire Resistance in Inductance Formula
questions.question_text: The inductance formula $L = \mu_0\mu_r N^2 A/\ell$ includes the DC resistance of the wire used to construct the coil.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! Inductance L depends only on geometry (N, A, $\ell$) and magnetic permeability $\mu$. Wire resistance R is a separate parasitic parameter.
questions.feedback_incorrect: False. Inductance is determined by magnetic properties, not wire resistance. R and L are independent parameters.

questions.title: Circuit Node Definition
questions.question_text: In circuit analysis, what precisely defines a node?
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A node is a connection point where two or more circuit elements meet, defining a common voltage point.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A node is an electrical junction point where multiple components connect, establishing a common potential.

questions.title: Circuit Branch Definition
questions.question_text: A branch in circuit analysis is best characterized as:
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! A branch connects two distinct nodes and may contain one or more circuit elements in series.
questions.feedback_incorrect: A branch is a current path connecting two nodes, potentially containing circuit components.

questions.title: Circuit Loop Definition
questions.question_text: What defines a loop in circuit topology?

questions.title: Phasor to Time Domain Conversion
questions.question_text: Convert the phasor $V = 120\angle 0\text{\degree}\,\text{V}$ at $\omega = 377\,\text{rad/s}$ to its time-harmonic signal form.
questions.feedback_correct: Correct! For phasor $V\angle\theta$, the time domain form is $v(t) = V \cos(\omega t + \theta)$. Here: $v(t) = 120\cos(377t + 0\text{\degree}) = 120\cos(377t)\,\text{V}$.
questions.feedback_incorrect: For phasor $V\angle\theta$, use $v(t) = V \cos(\omega t + \theta)$. With $\theta = 0\text{\degree}$, the result is $v(t) = 120\cos(377t)\,\text{V}$.
